awd_titl_txt: Integrating genetic, morphological, behavioral and demographic data to investigate primate life history
awd_abstract_narration:
Interpreting the human and primate fossil record is complicated by the fact that typically only skeletons and teeth are preserved. Yet many important aspects of primate and human biology are linked to variation in soft tissues, such as the degree of fat storage required for development and growth, or the degree of muscle development required for locomotion or within-species competition. In this project, the researchers will investigate the relationships among skeletons, soft-tissues, and reproduction across the lifespan, in the rhesus monkey population of Cayo Santiago, Puerto Rico. The project will advance knowledge about fundamental relationships among form, function, and behavior in non-human primates, which can inform our understanding of past primate and human biology. The project is an important part of research initiatives between New York University (NYU) and the Caribbean Primate Research Center, Puerto Rico, and builds on current initiatives to preserve and curate the Cayo Santiago skeletal collection as a valuable biological data resource. In addition, educational and public access programs will provide many opportunities for underrepresented minority students to participate in STEM research, both in the continental US and in Puerto Rico.
		
The usual absence of soft-tissues from the fossil record presents a big challenge for assessing reproductive life histories from skeletal data in order to estimate the phenotypic variation on which natural selection acted, and to reconstruct the evolution of our species. This study will combine soft-tissue measurements of two entire social groups with detailed analyses of the entire Cayo Santiago adult skeletal collection, demographic, genetic parentage, and behavioral data, collected over more than six decades. The researchers will determine whether and to what extent variation in skeletal traits relates to fleshed measures of body size, body mass, body fat, and muscle size in two groups; determine the genetic and environmental sources of variation in both skeletal and soft tissue traits, and; determine the extent to which skeletal markers and soft tissue markers predict differences in fecundity and longevity in both females and males. The methods will combine morphometric measurement of both soft and hard tissues with quantitative genetic approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we aimed to macerate and curate a new portion of the Cayo Santiago (Puerto Rico) rhesus macaque skeletal collection in New York city, and to collect and integrate data from this collection with other data types emerging from Cayo Santiago. This project had several components, starting with the maceration and transportation of specimens from Puerto Rico to New York. We then aimed to conduct and disseminate research combining skeletal data with other data types. We also aimed to undertake a number of other broader impacts.

Our project successfully curated and measured new skeletal material, and integrated this material with other diverse data types to meet the project’s aims. Two whole social groups were completely curated into the New York University portion of the Cayo Santiago skeletal collection, while a third social group is now almost fully curated. This has involved the implementation of a database-management system and a museum inventory protocol. Internal research projects are now underway using the collection, and multiple external researchers from other institutions have already visited to collect measurements and to use the collection for training and research.

The data that are emerging from the collection are also being integrated into a large new database that we are building alongside other collaborators. This database contains genomic, transcriptomic, physiological, behavioral, demographic, and other data, alongside the soft-tissue and hard-tissue morphological data that have been produced in the present project.

The ongoing analysis of data generated from the present project has resulted in the publication of the first manuscript from the project, in the American Journal of Biological Anthropology, which looks at the development of sexual dimorphism in the skeleton. A second manuscript has just been submitted for review, which links soft and hard tissue measurements. Two other manuscripts are now close to submission, including one which assess which skeletal measures are the best indicators of body mass.

The project has also had extensive additional broader impacts and outreach activities, including training and support of a junior Native American scholar as a postdoc, training of multiple masters students and NYC-based high school students from under-represented minority (URM) backgrounds at NYU, and outreach to high school students in San Juan.


Last Modified: 06/08/2023
Modified by: James Higham
